   105.01  DIVISION INTO WARDS.
   The City shall be divided into four wards, the boundaries of which shall be
as follows.
(Ord.  2002-67.  Passed 12-17-02.)
 
   105.02  FIRST WARD.
   All of the Corporation territory of the City lying north of the centerline
of East Main Street and east of the centerline of Whittlesey Avenue, excepting
therefrom that part of the corporation bounded as follows: centerline of Grand
Avenue from Whittlesey Avenue to Fruen Street, centerline of Fruen Street from
Grand Avenue to Cline Street, centerline of Cline Street from Fruen Street to
East League Street, centerline of East League Street from Cline Street to Milan
Avenue, centerline of Milan Avenue from East League Street to East Main Street,
centerline of East Main Street from Milan Avenue to Whittlesey Avenue,
centerline of Whittlesey Avenue from East Main Street to Grand Avenue.
(Ord. 2011-054.  Passed 12-20-11.)
 
   105.03  SECOND WARD.
   All of the Corporation territory of the City lying south of the centerline
of Main Street and east of the centerline of Benedict Avenue, and also
including the part of the Municipal Corporation bounded as follows: centerline
of East Main Street from Marshall Street to Wooster Street, centerline of
Wooster Street from East Main Street to Rule Street, centerline of Rule Street
from Wooster Street to Marshall Street, centerline of Marshall Street from Rule
Street to East Main Street.  (Ord. 2011-054.  Passed 12-20-11.)
 
   105.04  THIRD WARD.
   All of the Corporation territory of the City lying south of the centerline
of West Main Street and west of the centerline of Benedict Avenue, and also
including the part of the Municipal Corporation bounded as follows: centerline
of North Pleasant Street from West Main Street to Jefferson Street, centerline
of Jefferson Street from North Pleasant Street to State Street, centerline of
State Street from Jefferson Street to West League Street, centerline of West
League Street from State Street to North Foster Street, centerline of North
Foster Street from East League Street to Franklin Street, centerline of
Franklin Street from Foster Street to Lee Avenue, centerline of Lee Avenue from
Franklin Street to East League Street, centerline of East League Street from
Lee Avenue to Milan Avenue, centerline of Milan Avenue from East League Street
to Marshall Street, centerline of Marshall Street from Milan Avenue to Rule
Street, centerline of Rule Street from Marshall Street to Wooster Street,
centerline of Wooster Street from Rule Street to East Main Street, centerline
of East Main Street from Wooster Street to North Pleasant Street.
(Ord. 2011-054.  Passed 12-20-11.)
 
   105.05  FOURTH WARD.
   All of the Corporation territory of the City lying north of the centerline
of West Main Street and west of the centerline of Whittlesey Avenue, excepting
therefrom that part of the corporation bounded as follows: centerline of
Whittlesey Avenue from West League Street to West Main Street, the centerline
of West Main Street from Whittlesey Avenue to North Pleasant Street, the
centerline of North Pleasant Street from West Main Street to Jefferson Street,
the centerline of Jefferson Street from North Pleasant Street to State Street,
the centerline of State Street from Jefferson Street to West League Street, the
centerline of West League Street from State Street to Whittlesey Avenue and
also including the part of the Municipal Corporation bounded as follows:
centerline of Grand Avenue from Whittlesey Avenue to Fruen Street, centerline
of Fruen Street from Grand Avenue to Cline Street, centerline of Cline Street
from Fruen Street to East League Street, centerline of East League Street from
Cline Street to Lee Avenue, centerline of Lee Avenue from East League Street to
Franklin Street, centerline of Franklin Street from Lee Avenue to Foster
Street, centerline of Foster Street from Franklin Street to East League Street,
centerline of East League Street from Foster Street to Whittlesey Avenue,
centerline of Whittlesey Avenue from East League Street to Grand Avenue.
(Ord. 2011-054.  Passed 12-20-11.)

   121.01  EXPULSION OF MEMBERS.
   Council may punish or expel any member where any of the provisions of
Section
3.03 of the City Charter are applicable.  No expulsion shall take place until
such member has been notified of the charge against them and has had an
opportunity to be heard.
 
   121.02  CLERK OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   Duties.  The Clerk of Council shall attend all meetings, regular and
special, record all proceedings in the minutes, prepare an agenda for every
meeting, attend to all correspondence incidental to his office, attend to the
codification of ordinances, perform such other duties as may be assigned by a
majority vote of Council and perform all the duties required by the laws of the
State or the ordinances of the City.  The Clerk of Council shall also be the
Clerk of the Board of Zoning Appeals, the Clerk of the Business Development
Committee, the Clerk of the Charter Review Commission, and the Clerk of the
Planning Commission and shall perform such duties as may be assigned by such
boards and commissions.
   (b)   Compensation.  Council shall appoint the Clerk of Council and
determine the classification for compensation payable in bi-weekly
installments.
   (c)   Certification of Amendment.  The Clerk shall maintain one constantly
revised copy of the Codified Ordinances and shall certify copies of each
amendment or supplement thereto, to the officer or head of the department
affected thereby.
   (d)   Day to day supervision of the Clerk of Council shall be vested in the
Safety/Service Director.  In the absence of the Safety/Service Director, day to
day supervision of the Clerk of Council shall be vested in Law Director.
(Ord.  2019-011.  Passed 3-5-19.)
 
   121.03  QUORUM.
   A majority of all Council members elected shall be a quorum to do business,
but a smaller number may adjourn from day to day and compel the attendance of
absent members by fine.
(1961 Code Sec. 13)
 
   121.04  SMOKING BANNED.
   Council hereby bans smoking in Council Chambers and the jury room during all
work sessions and regular and special Council meetings.
(Ord. 87-73.  Passed 11-3-87.)

   123.01  VACATION OF STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   The following procedures shall be followed to accomplish the vacation of
City alleys and streets.
   (a)   By Petition.
      (1)   A lot owner in the City of Norwalk may file a petition with the
Clerk of Council for the vacation of an alley or street located in the
immediate vicinity of the property owned by such lot owner and shall be
required to file a two hundred dollar ($200.00) filing fee with the petition. 
In addition, the petitioner shall be required to provide an accurate plat
prepared by an engineer of the property to be vacated along with a proper legal
description.
         (Ord. 90-35.  Passed 4-3-90.)
      (2)   The Clerk of Council shall present such petition at the next
regularly scheduled meeting of Council after which time the petition shall be
referred to the appropriate committee of Council for consideration and
recommendation.
      (3)   The committee of Council shall thereafter refer the petition to the
Law Director for preparation of the appropriate legislation.
      (4)   The legislation shall be placed upon first reading and thereafter
referred to the Planning Commission for their recommendation.
      (5)   Upon receipt of the recommendation of the Planning Commission,
Council shall cause to be published for a period of six consecutive weeks,
notice of intention to vacate.
      (6)   Within a period of three weeks from the last publication Council
shall consider such ordinance for passage on second reading.
      (7)   If the ordinance is passed by Council, the Clerk of Council shall
submit the ordinance to the Huron County Auditor's Office and thereafter to the
Huron County Recorder's Office.
   (b)   Without Petition.  Upon a determination by Council that there is good
cause for vacating or narrowing a street or alley or any part thereof, and upon
a further finding that such vacation ordinarily will not be detrimental to the
general interests of the citizens of Norwalk, such street or alley may be
vacated after publication listed in subsection (a) hereof which shall be given
except when all of the owners of abutting property in the area to be vacated
have given written consent to the vacation thereof.
      (Ord. 86-12.  Passed 2-4-86.)
 
   123.02  SALE OF REAL PROPERTY.
   The following shall be the procedure for the sale of real estate owned by
the City of Norwalk:
   (a)   The continued usefulness and need of the property in question shall be
considered by the appropriate committee of Council at a meeting held with any
interested official or board involved in the use of such property.
   (b)   If an initial determination is made that the property is no longer
needed for Municipal purposes, a request for the preparation of necessary
legislation shall be made to the Law Director.
   (c)   Upon preparation of the necessary legislation, such legislation shall
be considered upon first reading by Council.
   (d)   The legislation shall then be referred to the Planning Commission for
approval and return to Council with a recommendation upon such sale.
   (e)   If passed upon second reading by at least two-thirds of the members of
Council and by the board or official having supervision or management of such
real estate, Council shall cause to be published an advertisement for bids for
five consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the City.
   (f)   Thereafter the responsible board or official shall consider all bids
and enter into a contract with the highest bidder or reject such bids.
      (Ord. 86-12.  Passed 2-4-86.)
 
   123.03  GENERAL CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND TRANSFERS.
   There shall be no transfer of funds from any General Capital Improvement
Fund line item without specific authorization through resolution by Norwalk
City Council.
(Ord. 2004-008.  Passed 3-9-04.)
   123.04  SALE OR DISPOSAL OF PERSONAL PROPERTY.
   The following shall be the procedure for the sale or disposal of personal
property owned by the City:
   (a)   Personal property not needed for municpal purposes, which in the
Service Director’s opinion has an estimated value of less than $2,000, may be
sold by any means deemed appropriate by the Service Director and approved by
the Mayor.
   (b)   Personal property not needed for municipal purposes, which in the
Service Director’s opinion has an estimated value of more than $2,000 shall
only be sold as authorized by a resolution or ordinance approved by Council.
   (c)   Where the City has vehicles, equipment, or machines which are not
needed or unfit for public use and where the City intends to purchase other
vehicles, equipment, or machinery of the same type, the Service Director shall
determine whether it is in the best interest of the City that such unneeded or
unfit vehicles, equipment or machinery be sold as trade-in for the purpose of
having such sale price credited against the purchase price of such other
vehicles, equipment or machinery and to complete the sale and purchase by a
single contract to be approved by the Mayor.
   (d)   If the Service Director and the department head of the department
which has control of municipal personal property determine that such property
is not needed for public use, or is obsolete, or unfit for use and that the
property has no value, then the property may be discarded or used as salvage.
      (Ord. 2018-002.  Passed 1-16-18.)
   123.05  LEASE OF REAL PROPERTY.
   Real property owned by the City not currently needed for municipal purposes
may be leased for such period of time and upon such terms and conditions as
Council, by ordinance, shall determine.  Any lease of real property containing
an option to purchase the property shall be considered a sale of real property
subject to Section
123.02.
(Ord. 2012-017.  Passed 4-3-12.)

165.02
 
   133.01  FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   (a)    Pursuant to Section
 5.04 of the Charter of The City of Norwalk, the Finance Director shall be
appointed by City Council in accordance with this Chapter.
   (b)    Day to day supervision of the Finance Director shall be vested in the
Chief Executive Officer.
   (c)    A performance review of the Finance Director shall be conducted on an
annual basis. The review shall be conducted by the Chief Executive Officer and
one member of Council appointed by the President of Council. The results of the
review shall be reduced to writing and shall be provided to all members of
Council.
   (d)    On or before November 01 of each year, Council shall fix the
compensation of the Finance Director in accordance with the Pay Ordinance for
the following calendar year.
(Ord.  2017-037.  Passed 11-7-17.)
   133.02  SELECTION OF FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   Upon the vacancy or imminent vacancy in the position of Finance Director,
Council shall proceed to fill the position in accordance with this Section.
   (a)      There is hereby established a Selection Board consisting of the
following members:
      (1)    The President of Council or his/her designee.
      (2)    Two members of Council appointed by the President of Council, one
of whom shall have been elected at large and one of whom shall have been
elected from wards.
      (3)    The Mayor or his/her designee, who shall be a non-voting member.
      (4)    The President of Council shall be the Chairperson of the Selection
Board.
   (b)    The procedure for the selection of the Finance Director shall be as
follows:
      (1)    The Mayor shall report the vacancy or imminent vacancy to the
President  of Council. The President shall appoint the Selection Board which
shall thereafter convene and determine the schedule and procedure to be
followed in selecting the Finance Director consistent with this Section.
      (2)    The preferred method of filling the vacancy shall be promotion
from  within. The Selection Board shall cause notice of such vacancy to be
posted in all departments of the City. The Board shall determine the deadline
for submission of responses and the material that shall constitute a qualifying
response and application. Upon expiration of the posting period, the Selection
Board shall proceed pursuant to subsection (4).
      (3)    In the event no existing employee applies for the position of
Finance Director, or all of the applicants fail to meet the minimum
qualifications of subsection (c) or are disqualified pursuant to subsection
(d), the Selection Board search outside of current City employees and shall
cause notice of the vacancy to be advertised in such mediums as the Board deems
appropriate. The Board shall determine the deadline for submission of responses
and the  material that shall constitute a qualifying response and application.
      (4)    Upon the expiration of the application deadline, the Selection
Board shall review the applications and disqualify all applicants  who do not
meet the  minimum requirements set forth in subsection (c) or who are
disqualified pursuant to subsection (d)(2) or by reason of failing to submit
complete and qualifying applications. The balance of the applications shall be
considered as candidates.
      (5)   The Selection Board shall then review and score the applications of
the candidates based upon the minimum qualifications and the criteria set forth
in subsection (d). Based thereon, the Selection Board shall certify the top
three candidates to City Council. In the event there are fewer than three
candidates, the Selection Board shall certify all of the candidates to City
Council.
      (6)    Upon receipt of the certified list from the Selection Board,
Council shall schedule and interview the candidates so certified. Based
thereon, Council shall appoint a Finance Director from among the candidates
certified. A majority vote shall be required to appoint the Finance Director.
   (c)    The minimum qualifications for the position of Finance Director are
as follows:
      (1)    A bachelor degree, or higher, in finance, accounting, business or
related  field.
      (2)    At least three years of experience with the Norwalk Finance
Department or in Ohio public finance as a director of finance or assistant
director of finance, or equivalent positions, with another Ohio political
subdivision.
   (d)    Candidates for the position of Finance Director shall be selected
from those applicants who meet the minimum criteria set forth in subsection (c)
and shall be evaluated on the following criteria:
      (1)    An evaluation of the candidate's prior service records as
reflected in the candidate's application, resume', reference check and
background check.
      (2)    The results of a criminal background check. Candidates with
criminal convictions within the immediately preceding ten years for misdemeanor
or felony violations of Revised Code Chapters 2907, 2913, 2915 or 2921, or
equivalent laws of other states or municipalities, or felony convictions for
offenses of violence or moral turpitude, shall be disqualified from
consideration. Candidates with criminal convictions older than ten years shall,
if not otherwise eliminated from the selection process, be permitted to explain
to the Selection Board the reasons the candidate believes such conviction or
convictions should not disqualify the candidate.
      (3)    A comparison of the candidate's qualifications with the minimum
qualifications set forth in subsection (c) and the position description.
      (4)    Individual interview candidates pursuant to the selection
procedure set forth in subsection (b).  (Ord.  2017-037.  Passed 11-7-17.)
   133.03  DISTRIBUTION OF INTEREST EARNINGS.
   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized to deposit and credit at his
discretion interest earnings to the respective funds from which they are
earned.
(Ord.  2017-037.  Passed 11-7-17.)
   133.04  UNIFORM INVESTMENT POLICY.
   The City of Norwalk shall establish and maintain a Uniform Investment Policy
in accordance with the requirements of the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord.  2019-041.  Passed 12-17-19.)
   133.05  CREDIT CARD POLICY.
   (a)   The City recognizes that the use of a credit card can facilitate City
business and provide an efficient means of making purchases on the City's
behalf. The City also recognizes the inherent risks associated with the use of
credit cards. Therefore, the use of City credit cards is restricted to those
situations where, by reason of time restraints or efficiency, the normal City
vendor policy and practice is not practicable. All use of City credit cards is
subject to the requirements and limitations of this Policy.
   (b)   Authorized Users of City Credit Cards.  City Council authorizes each
of the following positions, or such position's designee, to carry and use a
City of Norwalk (the City) credit card:
      General Services Superintendent
      Parks & Recreation Superintendent
      Chief of Police
      Chief of Fire
      Director of Finance
      Water Department Superintendent
      Waste Water Department Superintendent
      Clerk of the Municipal Court
      Director of Safety/Service
      Mayor
      Director of Public Works
      Director of Law
   The name of the City together with the City's tax identification number
shall appear on each City credit card.
   Each employee using a City credit card shall execute a written statement
affirming that the employee has received a copy of this Policy, that the
employee understands the Policy and the penalties for violating the Policy, and
that the employee agrees to abide by and be bound by the terms of this Policy.
   (c)   Types of Allowable Credit Card Expenses.  City credit cards shall only
be used in connection with City-approved or City-related activities and only
those types of expenses that are for the benefit of the City. All credit card
expenses shall serve a valid and proper public purpose. This includes accounts
that can be used to make purchases on credit even when no physical credit card
exists. The term credit card expressly excludes any procurement card account,
gas or telephone card account, or any other card account where merchant
category codes are in place as a system of control for use of the account.
   The following type of expenses are prohibited:
      (1)     Personal expenses;
      (2)   Purchase of food unrelated to City business;
      (3)   Purchases of alcohol or tobacco;
      (4)    Entertainment;
      (5)    Cash advances and money transfers;
      (6)    Other purchases as directed by the Finance Director.
   (d)   Procedure for Submitting Itemized Receipts.  The use of a credit card
does not eliminate the need for compliance with the City's purchase order
policies and procedures. Employees authorized to carry credit cards may use the
card for any expense deemed a proper public purpose, provided a purchase order
is in place in advance of the purchase. Itemized receipts must be returned to
the Finance Director or Assistant Director of Finance substantiating the exact
amount charged to the card. Gratuities in accordance with the USGSA guidelines
are acceptable. Every effort should be made by employees to notify and provide
vendors with an Ohio Sales Tax exempt form. If a merchant fails to waive the
tax, the employee and Finance Director are authorized to pay it contingent upon
the significance of the sales tax paid and department compliance history.
   (e)   Maximum Credit Limits.
      (1)   The Finance Director shall be responsible for reviewing available
credit card accounts and to determine which account type, account provider, and
credit limit best meets the needs of the City.  The Finance Director will
determine how many accounts, cards, and checks are to be issued and establish a
process for card reissuance or cancellation. Debit cards are prohibited by law.
      (2)   The City shall establish the following credit limits:
 
Department           Credit Monthly Limit
General Services     $30,000
Parks and Recreation $20,000
Police Department    $25,000
Fire Department      $25,000
Finance Department   $25,000
Water and Wastewater $25,000
Municipal Court      $5,000
Safety Service       $5,000
Mayor                $5,000
Law Department       $5,000
Public Works         $5,000
      (3)   The Finance Director may adjust the above limits based on emergency
or necessity. Limits shall be returned to their monthly limits immediately
after the transaction is processed. Individual purchases on any credit card is
limited to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) per transaction unless
a transaction in excess of such limit is authorized in advance by the Mayor or
his/her designee.
   (f)   Procedure for Acquisition, Use, and Management of Credit Card Accounts
and Card Themselves and the Procedure for Card Issuance, Reissuance,
Cancellation, and Process for
Lost/Stolen.
      (1)   The Finance Director shall coordinate with appropriate financial
institutions that issue credit cards to determine the best type of credit card
accounts for the City, and also to determine which store credit card accounts
the City will utilize.
      (2)   The Finance Director is responsible for working with the issuing
financial institution to determine the dates when credit cards expire and the
reissuance of replacement cards.
      (3)   The Finance Director is responsible for determining, when
necessary, the need to cancel a credit card account.
      (4)   The Finance Director is responsible for notifying the issuing
financial institution of a lost or stolen card. Employees using a credit card
shall notify the Finance Director or Assistant Finance Director within one
working day when they become aware that a card is lost or stolen.
   (g)   Actions that Qualify as Misuse by an Employee. 
      (1)   The following actions or omissions by an officer or employee
handling or using a City credit card shall constitute misuse of the credit
card:
         A.   Use of the credit card to make a purchase or transaction
prohibited by this policy;
         B.   Use of the credit card for purchases other than for City
business;
         C.   Permitting a person not authorized by this policy to handle or
use the credit card or credit card account;
         D.   Use of the credit card or credit card account by any person not
authorized to do so by this policy;
         E.   Failure to submit receipts following use of the credit card or
credit card account within one working day;
         F.   Use of the credit card or credit card account without complying
with the City's purchase order policy.
      (2)   Employees are liable in person and upon official bond for any
unauthorized use of credit and any employee who suspects the loss, theft, or
possibility of unauthorized use of a card must notify the Finance Director or
Assistant Finance Director immediately.
      (3)   Inappropriate or illegal use of the card and/or failure to strictly
adhere to the requirements set forth in the Finance Department's guidelines,
including submitting detailed itemized receipts, may result in loss of credit
card privileges, disciplinary action, up to and including termination, personal
responsibility for any and all charges, including finance charges and interest
assessed, and referral to law enforcement for prosecution. Employees shall be
responsible to make full reimbursement to the City within thirty days for any
charges that were not supported with detailed itemized receipts.
      (4)   Any employee of the City or other public servant as defined in Ohio
R.C. 2921.01 who knowingly misuses a City credit card or credit card account
may be criminally prosecuted under Ohio R.C. sections 2913.02, 2913.21, 2921.41
and 2921.42.
      (5)   In the event an itemized receipt was not secured to support the
credit card expense, the employee shall complete the City of Norwalk Credit
Card Lost Receipt Certification Form evidencing the credit card expense was for
a proper public purpose. The expense shall only be processed after approvals
from the employee, department head and Finance Director.
      (6)   A violation of this Policy shall constitute a Group 3 offense under
the City's disciplinary policy which may result in termination of employment
without prior disciplinary history. A violation of this Policy shall also
result in the loss of privileges to use the City credit card.
   (h)   Compliance Officer and Review.
      (1)   The Assistant Finance Director shall be the designated Compliance
Officer. The Compliance Officer shall not use a City credit card or credit card
account and may not authorize any person to use a City credit card or credit
card account. The Compliance Officer shall also be responsible for compiling a
list of rewards received from credit card usage and such report shall be
submitted to City Council annually.
      (2)   On a quarterly basis, the Compliance Officer shall review the
number of City credit cards and accounts issued, the number of active cards and
accounts issued, the cards' and accounts' expiration dates, and the cards' and
accounts' credit limits, and shall report the same to City Council. On a
quarterly basis, Council shall review the information contained in the report
of the Compliance officer.
         (Ord.  2019-006.  Passed 2-5-19.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 135
Department of Law
 
135.01   Limits of City liability.
135.02   Reimbursement of medical cost.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Powers and duties - see CHTR. Sec.
5.03; Ohio R.C. 733.51
      Qualifications - see Ohio R.C. 733.50
      Prosecuting attorney of Mayor's Court - see Ohio R.C. 733.51
      Payment over of money - see Ohio R.C. 733.55
      Annual report to Council - see Ohio R.C. 733.62
 
   135.01  LIMITS OF CITY LIABILITY.
   (a)   For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
      (1)   "Action in Tort" means claims, demands, actions, of suits based
upon negligence, errors and omissions, nuisance, malpractice, intentional tort,
products' liability, strict liability, and includes, but is not limited to the
following theories: false arrest, false imprisonment, wrongful eviction,
wrongful detention, malicious prosecution, discrimination, humiliation,
invasion of privacy, libel, slander, defamation of character, false light,
piracy and infringement of copyright or of property, erroneous service of civil
or criminal papers, violation of civil rights, assault and battery,
disparagement of property, inverse condemnation, and also includes, but is not
limited to, claims, demands, actions or suits, wherein the injuries include
property damage, bodily injury, mental injury, mental anguish, emotional
distress, shock, sickness, disease, disability, loss of wages, and loss of
earning capacity, and also includes wrongful death and survival-type actions.
      (2)   "Occurrence" means an accident or happening of event or a
continuous or repeated exposure to conditions which results in personal injury,
or damage to property.  All such exposure to substantially the same general
conditions existing at or emanating from one location shall be deemed one
occurrence.
      (3)   "Public employee" means any employee, officer, official, whether
elected or appointed, including any judicial officer, Clerk of Court or
employee thereof, and any paid or unpaid employee, representative or agent of
the City, whether or not identifiable by name.
      (4)   "Non-statutory basis" means based upon case-made law.
      (5)   "Statutory basis" means based upon any enacted law, whether State,
federal, or municipal, whether or not the law is expressed as a statute,
ordinance, code, rule, regulation or directive.
 
   (b)   All actions in tort against public employees, while acting in the
scope of their authority, and the City for death, personal injury or property
damage shall be subject to the provisions of this section.  All statutory and
nonstatutory law, substantive or procedural, concerning claims against the City
or public employee shall continue with full force and effect except as
otherwise provided by this section.  In the event any provisions of this
section shall be determined to be unconstitutional, ultra vires or otherwise
unenforceable as a matter of law, the remaining provisions shall to the extent
possible continue with full force and effect.
 
   (c)   Subject to the limitations imposed by this section, the payments of
claims and judgment, approved for payment, where the City or a public employee
is or may be liable, shall be limited to available, unencumbered funds that
have been specifically appropriated on an annual basis for payment of claims
and judgments.  Partial payments of claims or judgments may be made over
successive years from funds subsequently appropriated.  Priority of payment of
carried over claims shall be given based on the date of the occurrence giving
rise to liability.  Priority of payment of carry-over judgments shall be given
to the filing date of the judgment.
 
   (d)   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall annually submit to the
Council a recommended appropriation for payment of claims and judgments.  In
making such recommendation, the following non-exclusive information may be
considered:
      (1)   The past judgments and claims payments by the City;
      (2)   The monetary risk of all litigation against the City;
      (3)   The reasonable value of known unasserted claims and litigation;
      (4)   Necessary reserves to promote financial stability of the City;
      (5)   Priorities of City service delivery;
      (6)   Projected expansion or contraction of City income;
      (7)   Comparative data relative to payment of claims and judgments of the
eight most populous cities of the State of Ohio;
      (8)   Unsatisfied judgments and claims approved for payment in previous
years;
      (9)   Overall financial stability of the City.
 
   (e)   The amount of damages recoverable against the City and any public
employee for death, personal injury or property damage arising out of a single
occurrence, or sequence of occurrences shall be limited as follows:
      (1)   When the City or public employee has insurance coverage for an
occurrence or sequence of occurrences, payment of claims and judgments in which
the City or a public employee is or may be liable and obligated to pay may be
made to the extent insurance proceeds or insurance indemnification is available
and payable, in addition to any deductibles or self-insurance retention
required by applicable insurance contracts.
      (2)   When the City or public employee has no insurance coverage relative
to an occurrence or sequence of occurrences, the extent to which the City and
public employee are obligated to pay damages shall be as follows:
         A.   When the City and public employee is or may be jointly or
severably liable for actions in tort under Ohio R.C. 723.01, 701.02, or other
statute, or combination of statutory and non-statutory bases, a sum not in
excess of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000) per person and five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) per occurrence, provided unencumbered funds
are available and have been appropriated for such payment;
         B.   When the City or public employee is or may be, jointly or
severably, liable for actions in tort based solely on an non-statutory basis, a
sum not in excess of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000) per person
and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,00) per occurrence, provided
unencumbered funds are available and have been appropriated for such payment;
         C.   The aggregate liability of the City for a single accident or
occurrence or sequence of accidents or occurrences, shall be apportioned
equitably among all claimants and judgment holders therefor.
 
   (f)   This section shall not be construed to prevent Council from
authorizing the purchase of liability insurance for the City and public
employees as named insureds and persons insured, or to authorize payment of any
agreed deductibles, self-insurance retention or amounts subject to
indemnification required by the applicable insurance contracts.
 
   (g)   Regarding any occurrence in which the City or public employee is or
may be liable, the City shall not pay, nor be obligated to pay any amount for
punitive or exemplary damages whatsoever.
 
   (h)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to abrogate or restrict any
immunity or right of indemnification of the City or public employee, whether by
insurance or otherwise, or to confer a right or action upon any person against
the City or public employee, nor shall anything in such sections be construed
to impose liability on the City or public employee for any negligent or
wrongful act or omission.
 
   (i)   The limitations set forth in this section shall apply to all
occurrences prior to the effective date of this section which occurrences may
give right to a claim, demand, action or suit made or filed after the effective
date of this section.
 
   (j)   The limitations set forth in this section shall also apply to all
occurrences which give rise to actions in tort after the effective date of this
section.
(Ord. 85-27.  Passed 5-21-85.)
 
   135.02  REIMBURSEMENT OF MEDICAL COST.
   (a)   Whenever an individual is convicted of a criminal or traffic offense,
other than a minor misdemeanor and such individual during the pendency of any
incarceration requires medical treatment which is paid for by the City of
Norwalk, such individual shall reimburse the City the cost of such treatment
paid within 30 days of their release from confinement.
 
   (b)   The Director of Law may cause to be brought an action, in the
appropriate venue in the name of the City, a civil law suit against any
individual who fails to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) hereof.
 
   (c)   The Director of Law in the event he chooses to bring an action
specified in this section shall request interest at the judgment interest rate
in such lawsuit.
(Ord. 94-95.  Passed 8-16-94.)

   139.01  CIVIL ENGINEERING SERVICE.

   139.02  PART-TIME AND PROBATIONARY OFFICE EMPLOYEES.
   Part-time office employees and probationary office employees may be employed
in the various departments of the City, upon approval by the department head
and the Director of Public Service and Safety, and shall receive compensation
in biweekly installments from the General Fund.
(Ord. 72-77.  Passed 11-21-72.)
 
   139.03  OFFICE MANAGER.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service and Safety is empowered to appoint an
Office Manager to provide common supporting services in an efficient manner to
the Operating, Executive, Legislative and Purchasing Departments.
 
   (b)   The Office Manager shall be paid bi-weekly.  Twenty-five percent (25%)
of his salary shall be derived from the General Fund; twenty-five percent (25%)
from the Sewer Fund; twenty-five percent (25%) from the Street Fund and twenty-
five percent (25%) from the Water Fund.
(Ord. 83-1.  Passed 1-4-83.)
 
   139.04  CITY ENGINEER AND ASSISTANT BUILDING INSPECTOR.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety is empowered to appoint a City
Engineer and Assistant Building Inspector to assist in developing plans for
various City activities.

CHAPTER 145

   145.01  COMPOSITION.
   (a)   There shall be a Chief of Police.  The Police Department shall further
consist of three captains, five sergeants and up to sixteen regular patrolmen
and such reserve or special patrolmen as shall be deemed necessary by the
Service/Safety Director, with such duties as assigned by the Chief of Police.
 
   (b)   The Chief of Police may appoint a Secretary of Police who shall be the
executive officer.  The executive officer shall fulfill those duties of
secretary of Police as imposed by general law and such other duties as assigned
by the Chief of Police.
 
   (c)   When a vacancy occurs in a position with a rank above patrolman, the
Mayor may appoint a patrolman to fulltime employment prior to the completion of
the promotion process provided the total number of fulltime officers does not
exceed 25.
(Ord. 2014-036.  Passed 12-2-14.)
 
   145.02  QUALIFICATIONS.
   Each applicant for appointment as a regular, must conform to the following
rules and requirements: (A.O.)
   (a)   Shall be a citizen of the United States and shall meet residency
requirements of City of Norwalk Personnel Policy Manual Section 3.6.
      (Ord. 2000-77.  Passed 10-17-00.)
   (b)   Shall have had at least a high school education or its equivalent.
   (c)   Shall not have been convicted of any felony in any State or Federal
court.
   (d)   Shall pass any and all examinations, to be given by the Civil Service
Commission.
 
   145.03  GENERAL DUTIES.
   The police force shall preserve the peace, protect persons and property and
obey and enforce all ordinances of the City and all criminal laws of the State
and of the United States, and perform such other duties as Council by ordinance
may prescribe.  The Police Department shall be maintained under the civil
service system, as provided by law.
(1961 Code Sec. 147)
 
   145.04  DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The Police Chief shall regulate the operations of the Police Department and
shall prescribe the uniforms and equipment to be worn by the members of the
force.
(1961 Code Sec. 148)
 
   145.05  CLASSIFICATION.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall classify the service in the
Police Department in conformity with the ordinances of Council determining the
number of persons to be employed therein, and shall make all rules for the
regulation and discipline of the members of the Police Department, except as
otherwise provided by law.
(1961 Code Sec. 149)
 
   145.06  EMERGENCY PATROLMEN.
   In case of riot or other like emergency  or critical shortage of manpower,
the Mayor may appoint additional patrolmen and officers for temporary service,
who need not be in the classified list of the Police Department.
(Ord. 90-71.  Passed 7-31-90.)
 
   145.07  SPECIAL POLICE ALARM SYSTEM.
   Banks and other private institutions are granted the right to have installed
a police alarm system, to be connected with the City Police Headquarters, upon
the condition that the cost of installation and maintenance of such alarm
system shall be borne entirely by such institution receiving such special
service.
(Ord. 90-71.  Passed 7-31-90.)
 
   145.08  ATTENDANCE AT SCHOOLS OF INSTRUCTION.
   The Chief, officers and members of the Police Department are hereby
authorized to attend schools of instruction, subject to the approval of the
Director of Finance.  The dues and expenses of each membership and attendance
may be paid from the General Fund is such amount as shall be approved by the
Director.
(Ord. 90-71.  Passed 7-31-90.)
 
   145.09  SCHOOL ZONE SAFETY PATROLMEN.
   The Director of Service and Safety may employ school zone safety patrolmen,
who shall possess the qualifications as shall be determined by the Director of
Service and Safety, who shall also make rules and regulations for such
patrolmen.
(Ord. 90-71.  Passed 7-31-90.)
 
   145.10  RESERVE POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   Established; Members.  There is created within the Department of
Public Safety a reserve police unit, the members of which shall be appointed by
the Director of Public Service and Safety.
 
   (b)   Term of Service.  Reserve police officers shall serve so long as the
Director of Public Service and Safety may direct, or until a resignation
submitted by any member shall be accepted by the Director.
 
   (c)   Qualifications.  Reserve police officers shall be citizens of the
United States and shall live within a radius of twenty-five miles of the
intersection of Main Street and Whittlesey/Benedict Avenue, but need not be
electors of the City.  Members may not be under the age of twenty-one years. 
Reserve officers shall meet other requirements as established by the Director
of Public Service and Safety.
 
   (d)   Control of Unit.  The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer
of the reserve police unit and shall have control of the assignment, training,
stationing and the direction of work of such unit.  Reserve police officers
will have all police powers upon the successful completion of a course of
training as prescribed by the Ohio Peace Officer Training Council.  Reserve
police officers shall perform only such police duties as assigned by the Chief
of Police.  Such Reserve members shall obey the chain of command of the
Department and shall take orders from all regular appointed members thereof. 
The Chief of Police shall prescribe the hours of duty of the reserve police
officers.
 
   (e)   Rules and Regulations.  The Director of Public Service and Safety
shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the organization, administration,
conduct and control of the reserve police unit.
 
   (f)   Uniforms.  The Chief of Police is authorized to prescribe, by the
rules and regulations, the type of uniform which shall be worn by members of
the reserve police unit.
 
   (g)   Credit for Appointment to Police Department.  For purposes of original
appointments to the regular Norwalk Police Department any member of the Norwalk
Police Reserve Unit who has successfully completed two years continuous service
shall be granted an additional twenty percent (20%) credit of his total credit
given in the regular examination for appointment in which received a passing
grade.  Such credit shall be in addition to the Veteran's Preference granted by
Ohio R.C. 124.23.
(Ord. 93-34.  Passed 6-1-93.)
 
   (h)   Nonliability.  This section is declared by Council to be an exercise
by the City of its police powers for the protection of public peace, health,
property, safety and general welfare, and neither the City nor any agent nor
representative of the City, an officer appointed under the provisions of this
chapter, or any individual, firm, partnership, corporation, or the receiver or
trustees or any other agent thereof, who in good faith, executes any executive
order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this
section shall be liable for injury or damage sustained to person or property as
the direct or proximate result of such action.
(A.O.)
 
   145.11  WORKING HOURS.
   The maximum working hours for full-time police officers shall not exceed
forty hours in any one week, except when necessary as determined by the Chief
of Police and approved by the Chief of Police or Officer in charge with final
approval by the Chief of Police.  Time and a half will be paid for extra time
over forty hours in a seven consecutive day period.  Compensatory time and a
half off may be taken in lieu of payment, if mutually agreed by the Chief of
Police and the officer.
(Ord. 84-5.  Passed 1-17-84.)
 
   145.12  SELECTION OF CHIEF.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Selection Board consisting of the
following individuals:
      (1)   The President of Council or his/her designee chosen from among the
members of Council.
      (2)   The Chairperson of the Civil Service Commission or his/her designee
from among the members of the Commission.
      (3)   The Director of Service and Safety.
      (4)   A citizen representative of the City recommended by the Safety
Committee of Council and finally selected by Council as a whole.
      (5)   An expert in the respective fields of police or fire department
management to be selected by members of subsections (1), (2) and (3) hereof.
   (b)   The President of Council or his/her designee shall be the chairperson
of the Selection Board.
   (c)   The eligibility criteria for consideration as a candidate for the
position of Fire or Police Chief shall be the following:
      (1)   The applicant shall have at least ten years of service with the
respective department.
      (2)   The applicant maintains the rank of Captain in either of the
respective departments for a minimum of one year; or the rank of lieutenant of
the Fire Department or Sergeant of the Police Department for a minimum of three
years.
      (3)   In the event that no applicant possessing the above qualifications
shall apply for the position of Chief of Police or Chief of Fire, the
procedures contained in Ohio R.C. 124.44 and 124.45 shall be followed.
   (d)   Candidates shall be selected from among those eligible as indicated in
subsection (c) hereof on the following criteria:
      (1)   An evaluation of individual candidate's prior service record.
      (2)   The results of psychological examinations performed by qualified
examiners.  The psychological examination shall include an evaluation of the
candidate’s fitness and suitability to command and to assume and perform the
duties of the position of Chief and may include such other psychological,
emotional, personality and mental health evaluations or assessments as the
Selection Board may determine to be appropriate.  The psychological examination
may also include a psychiatric examination if such is recommended in the
psychological evaluation and deemed necessary by the Selection Board.  As a
condition of consideration for the position of Chief, all candidates shall
execute any and all authorizations necessary to cause full and complete written
results of all examinations/evaluations to be released to and utilized by the
Selection Board.
      (3)   Passage of a written examination administered by the Civil Service
Commission and involving both police or fire work testing and leadship
capabilities.  A minimum score for passage of this test shall be determined by
the Civil Service Commission prior to testing and this grade shall be
communicated to the candidates prior to the examinations.
      (4)   Individual interviews of the candidates by the Selection Board
members.
   (e)   The procedure for the selection of the Chief of Police or the Chief of
the Fire Department shall be as follows:
      (1)   The Mayor reports the vacancy to the President of Council.
      (2)   The President of Council as Chairperson of the Selection Board,
convenes a meeting of the permanent members of the Board and informs the Safety
Committee of the City for the selection of the citizen member.
      (3)   The Selection Board chooses the police or fire management expert.
      (4)   The Mayor notifies the qualified members of the Police and/or Fire
Departments and provides applications to the qualified applicants.
      (5)   Upon the expiration of the ten-day period, the Mayor delivers all
qualified applications to the President of Council as the Chairperson of the
Selection Board.
      (6)   The Chairperson of the Selection Board notifies the Civil Service
Commission, who then provides for the testing procedures as outlined in this
section and upon completion submits the test results to the Selection Board.
      (7)   The Selection Board, upon reception of the test results from the
Civil Service Commission, conducts the individual interviews pursuant to
subsection (d)(4) and makes a selection based upon the criteria set out in
subsection (d) hereof.  The name of the candidate selected shall then be
certified to the Mayor.  Upon certification by the Selection Board, the Mayor
shall appoint the certified candidate.
      (8)   In the event that no persons within the departments possessing the
qualifications set forth in subsection (c) or in Ohio R.C. 124.44 and 124.45
apply for the position of Chief or passes the examinations and interviews set
forth in subsection (d), the Selection Board may solicit from outside of the
respective departments.  Any candidate from outside of the respective
departments shall meet the years of service qualifications set forth in
subsection (c) in a full-time Police or Fire Department.
   (f)   Ohio R.C. 124.34 shall govern the demotion, suspension and removal of
the candidate selected pursuant to the above criteria.
(Ord.  2019-039.  Passed 12-3-19.)
 
   145.13  UNCLAIMED PROPERTY CONTRIBUTED TO PUBLIC AGENCIES OR NONPROFIT
ORGANIZATIONS.
   (a)   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to contribute property that
is unclaimed for more than sixty days to one or more public agencies, to one or
more nonprofit organizations no part of the net income of which inures to the
benefit of any private shareholder or individual and no substantial part of the
activities of which consists of carrying on propaganda or otherwise attempting
to influence legislation, or to one or more organizations satisfying Section
501(C)(3) or (C)(19) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
   (b)   The authority given to the Chief by this section shall only apply to
items which the Chief has a good faith belief have a worth of less than one
thousand dollars ($1,000) and a report shall be forwarded quarterly to the Law
Director detailing all items so contributed and the name of each agency
receiving such contribution.
(Ord.  2013-041.  Passed 8-20-13.)

   147.01  COMPOSITION.
   (a)   There shall be a Fire Chief and one Assistant Fire Chief.  The Fire
Department shall further consist of three captains, three lieutenants and up to
eleven firefighter drivers, all of whom shall be full-time employees and such
temporary firemen as the Chief or other officer in charge at any fire or
emergency may summon to the aid of the Department in such emergencies.
   (b)   The Fire Chief may appoint a Secretary of Fire who shall be the
executive officer such appointment shall be only for such time as there exists
a vacancy in the position of Assistant Fire Chief and shall terminate upon the
appointment of an Assistant Fire Chief. The executive officer shall fulfill
those duties of Secretary of Fire as imposed by general law and such other
duties as assigned by the Fire Chief.
   (c)    With the exception of the positions of Chief and Assistant Fire
Chief, all promotions and eligibility within the Fire Department will be
specified by state law.   
(Ord.  2019-031.  Passed 9-24-19.)
 
   147.02  GENERAL DUTIES.
   The Fire Department shall protect the lives and property of the people in
case of fire, and shall perform such other duties as Council prescribes.  All
full-time firemen shall be maintained under the civil service system.
(Ord. 62-14.  Passed 7-10-62.)
 
   147.03  CLASSIFICATION.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall classify the service in the
Fire Department in conformity with the ordinances of Council determining the
number of persons to be employed therein and shall make all rules and
regulations of the Department except as otherwise provided by law.
(1961 Code Sec. 182)
 
   147.04  DUTIES OF FIRE CHIEF; ADDITIONAL FIREMEN.
   The Chief of the Fire Department shall have exclusive control of the
stationing and transferring of all firemen and other officers and employees in
the Department and shall serve as the coordinator of the Ambulance Service
Division, under such general rules and regulations as the Director of Public
Service and Safety prescribes.  The Chief shall prescribe the uniforms and
equipment to be worn by members of the Department.  In cases of riot or other
like emergency, the Mayor may appoint additional firemen and officers for
temporary service, who need not be in the classified list of the Department,
and who shall be employed only for the duration of such emergency.
(Ord. 83-22.  Passed 5-17-83.)
 
   147.05  ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEF.
   (a)    The Assistant Fire Chief shall assist the Fire Chief in carrying out
those functions set forth in Section
147.04. The Assistant Chief shall perform administrative and managerial duties
over the Fire Department as assigned by the Fire Chief. In absence of the Fire
Chief the Assistant Chief shall exercise the authority and duties of the Fire
Chief and shall serve as Acting Chief.
   (b)   The selection of the Assistant Chief shall be by competitive
examination as set forth herein.
   (c)   The eligibility criteria for considerations as a candidate for the
position of Assistant Fire Chief shall be the following:
      (1)    The applicant shall have at least twenty-four (24) months of
service beyond the probationary period as a Norwalk Fire Department Captain or
Norwalk Fire Department Lieutenant, or combination of service in both ranks
totaling at least twenty-four (24) months of service beyond the probationary
service in either rank.
      (2)    Applications for the position of Assistant Fire Chief shall first
be accepted only from among those Captains in the Norwalk Fire Department who
meet the eligibility criteria set forth in subsection (c)(1) above. In the
event no Captain in the Norwalk Fire Department shall apply for the position of
Assistant Fire Chief or pass the examination therefor, applications shall be
accepted from among those Lieutenants in the Norwalk Fire Department who meet
the eligibility criteria set forth in subsection (c)(1) above.
      (3)    In the event that no Captain or Lieutenant in the Norwalk Fire
Department possessing the above qualifications shall apply for the position of
Assistant Fire Chief or pass the examination therefor, the City may accept
applicants from outside the Norwalk Fire Department provided such applicants
have the required number of years of service set forth in subsection (c)(1) in
a full-time fire department.
   (d)    The Assistant Chief shall be selected from among the eligible
candidates as determined in subsection (c) hereof based upon the following:
      (1)    The results of an evaluation or evaluations performed by qualified
examiners. The evaluation shall include an evaluation of the candidate's
fitness and suitability to command and to assume and perform the duties of the
position of Assistant Chief and may include such other psychological,
emotional, personality and mental health evaluations or assessments as deemed
appropriate by the Fire Chief and the Mayor. As a condition of consideration
for the position of Assistant Chief, all candidates shall execute any and all
authorizations necessary to cause full and complete written results of the
evaluations to be released to and utilized by the City.
      (2)    Passage of a written examination administered by the Civil Service
Commission testing the candidates' knowledge of Norwalk Fire Department
policies and procedures and such portions of the Norwalk Codified Ordinances
and Personnel Policy Manual as may be applicable to the Fire Department. The
Civil Service Commission shall set the minimum passing score.
      (3)    An evaluation of the candidate's prior service record. The Civil
Service Commission shall establish points to be added or subtracted from the
candidate's total combined score of subsections (d)(1) and (2), based upon
length of service, education pertaining to the fire service achieved while a
fire fighter, and disciplinary history.
   (e)    The Mayor shall appoint as Assistant Fire Chief the candidate with
the highest combine score from subsection (d).
   (f)    Ohio Revised Code section 124.34 shall govern the discipline,
demotion, suspension and removal of the Assistant Fire Chief.
(Ord.  2019-031.  Passed 9-24-19.)
 
   147.06  FIRE PROTECTION OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)   The Mayor may enter into an agreement with a political subdivision
other than the City of Norwalk to provide fire protection to the other
political subdivision.
   (b)   The following terms and conditions of any agreement mentioned in
subsection (a) hereof shall be included within any agreement:
      (1)   Fee.
         A.   A fee to be determined as reasonable and as set by a legislative
enactment of the City of Norwalk and the involved political subdivision.
         B.   The fee shall commence to be charged upon any equipment leaving
the fire station in the City of Norwalk.
      (2)   The amount of trucks, drivers and firemen furnished to another
political subdivision shall be determined by the fire officer in charge.
      (3)   All towing charges for equipment at the scene of an emergency shall
be paid by the respective political subdivision and not by the City of Norwalk.
   (c)   The Norwalk Fire Department may provide fire protection and emergency
services to any governmental entity in Ohio or another jurisdiction without a
contract, upon the approval of the legislative authority consistent with Ohio
R.C. 9.60(D)(1).
(Ord. 2003-042.  Passed 5-20-03.)
 
   147.07  ATTENDANCE AT SCHOOLS OF INSTRUCTION.
   The Chief, officers and firemen of the Fire Department are hereby authorized
to attend schools of instruction, subject to the approval of the Director of
Finance.  The dues and expenses of such membership and attendance may be paid
from the General Fund in such amount as shall be approved by the Director.
 
   147.08  QUALIFICATIONS OF FULL-TIME FIREFIGHTER.
   Each applicant for appointment as a regular full-time firefighter shall
conform to the following rules and requirements: 
   (a)   Shall be a citizen of the United States and shall meet residing
requirements of City of Norwalk Personnel Policy Manual Section 3.6.
   (b)   Shall have a high school education or its equivalent.
   (c)   Shall be between the ages of eighteen and forty, inclusive.
   (d)   Shall not have been convicted of any felony in any state or Federal
court.
   (e)   Shall pass a physical examination to be given by a physician named by
the Civil Service Commission.
      (Ord. 2013-017.  Passed 4-2-13.)
 
   147.09  QUALIFICATIONS OF VOLUNTEER FIREMEN.
   Each applicant for appointment as a volunteer fireman shall conform to the
following rules and requirements:
   (a)   Shall be a citizen of the United States and shall live within a radius
of eight miles of the intersection of Main Street and Whittlesey/Benedict
Avenue, but need not be electors of the City.
      (Ord. 79-14.  Passed 2-20-79.)
   (b)   Shall have had a high school education or its equivalent.
   (c)   Shall be between the ages of eighteen and forty.
      (Ord. 75-16.  Passed 4-15-75.)
   (d)   Shall successfully pass an examination to be given by the Chief of the
Fire Department.
   (e)   Shall not have been convicted of any felony in any state or Federal
Court.
   (f)   Shall pass a physical examination to be given by a physician named by
the Board of Control.
      (Ord. 62-14.  Passed 7-10-62.)
 
   147.10  SELECTION OF CHIEF.
   The selection of the Chief of the Fire Department shall be as provided in
Section
145.12.
(Ord. 2008-017.  Passed 4-15-08.)

   151.01  CLERK OF THE BOARD OF CONTROL.
   The Board of Control shall appoint a Clerk, who shall be a person other than
the Clerk of Council, to serve as Clerk to the Board of Control, and who shall
be the keeper of records and perform such other duties as the Board may assign.
(Ord. 94-85.  Passed 8-2-94.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 153
Treasury Investment Board
 
153.01   Composition.
153.02   Investments.
153.04   Bond.
153.03   Duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      See sectional histories for similar State law
      Treasury investment account - see Ohio R.C. 731.56 et seq.
 
   153.01  COMPOSITION.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Treasury Investment Board which shall
consist of the Mayor, Finance Director and Law Director.
 
   (b)   The Treasury Investment Board shall appoint a Clerk, who shall be a
person other than the Clerk of Council, to serve as Clerk to the Treasury
Investment Board, and who shall be the keeper of records and perform such other
duties as the Board may assign.
(Ord. 94-86.  Passed 8-2-94.)
 
   153.02  INVESTMENTS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the City which will not be
required to be used by the City for a period of six months or more, such moneys
may, in lieu of being deposited in a bank, be invested in accordance with the
City’s Uniform Investment Policy and Ohio R.C. 135.14.  (Ord. 2012-013.  Passed
3-6-12.)
 
   153.03  DUTIES.
   The duties of the Treasury Investment Board shall be:
   (a)   Whenever any obligations of the City are to be sold and the same are
not taken by the Finance Director, or when the obligations are otherwise
available for purchase by the City, the Finance Director shall submit to the
Mayor and to the Law Director a statement of the moneys in the Treasury or in
the process of collection and a schedule showing the probable requirements of
money for the use of the City for such period, not less than six months, as the
Mayor shall direct, together with a recommendation as to whether any moneys in
the Treasury should be invested in such obligations.  The Board may thereupon
order the investment of money in the Treasury in such obligation at not more
than the current market value, as it may deem advisable in the interest of the
City.  However, it shall not be necessary to advertise the bonds before the
investment is made, and no investment shall be made except in obligations which
have been passed upon and approved as to validity by a reputable firm of bond
attorneys.
   (b)   Whenever it is necessary to convert any such investments into cash, it
shall be done by selling such investments in any manner authorized by law for
the sale of investments, provided that no such obligation shall be sold for
less than the current market value.
      (1961 Code Sec. 232)
 
   153.04  BOND.
   The members of the Treasury Investment Board shall provide bonds to the City
in the sum of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000) each, conditioned for
the faithful performance of their duties, which bonds shall be in addition to
other bonds required by law of the members of the Treasury Investment Board. 
The premiums for such bonds shall be paid by the City from the General Funds.
(1961 Code Sec. 233)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 155
Civil Service Commission
 
   EDITOR'S NOTE:  There are no sections in Chapter
155.  This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references
and future legislation.

CHAPTER 157
Board of Architectural Review
 
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  The provisions of Chapter
157 go into effect upon receipt of the Revitalization Grant from the State of
Ohio for the Norwalk Community Revitalization Project.
 
157.01   Purpose.
157.02   District boundaries.
157.03   Members; Secretary; meetings.
157.04   Terms; vacancies.
157.05   Application and notice.
157.06   Standards for review; certificate of appropriateness.
157.07   Preservation of property upon demolition of a structure.
157.08   Repair or maintenance exception.
157.09   Appeals.
157.10   Planning Commission jurisdiction; City boards and commissions.
157.99   Penalty.
 
   157.01  PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to maintain a high character of community
development, to protect and preserve the property values and to protect real
estate from impairment or destruction of value for the general community
welfare by reviewing any proposed changes of the exterior architectural
characteristics of structures through the hereafter defined Architectural
District. It is the further purpose of this chapter to recognize and preserve
the distinctive historical and architectural character of this community which
has been greatly influenced by the architecture of an earlier period in this
community's history. These purposes will be served by the review of exterior
design, use of materials, the finish grade line, landscaping and orientation of
all structures altered, constructed, reconstructed, erected, enlarged, in the
defined Architectural District.
(Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.02  DISTRICT BOUNDARIES.
   There is hereby established an Architectural District which shall include
all lots that front on the area of Main Street, commencing at Case/Church
Street and extending to Foster Street; and on Whittlesey/Benedict Avenue,
commencing at Ohio Street/Railroad Avenue and extending to Water Street. (Ord.
95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.03  MEMBERS; SECRETARY; MEETINGS.
   The Board of Architectural Review shall consist of seven members, all of
whom shall be residents of the City, and who shall be appointed by the Mayor.
The Board shall have the authority to appoint a Secretary who shall be the
keeper of records of such Board and the Board shall have further authority to
enact by-laws and rules of procedure governing its operation. The Board shall
meet at a time, day and location selected by the Board. (Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-
5-95.)
 
   157.04  TERMS; VACANCIES.
   (a)    Length of Term and Appointing Authority.
      The terms of the Board of Architectural Review members shall be as
follows:
      (1)   Two persons shall be appointed for one year.
      (2)   Two persons shall be appointed for two years.
      (3)   Three persons shall be appointed for three years.
      Thereafter, all appointments shall be made for a full four year term.
 
   (b)    Vacancies.  Members of the Board of Architectural Review shall vacate
his/her office:
      (1)   Be ceasing to be a resident of the City; or
      (2)   By death; or
      (3)   By written resignation filed with the Secretary of the Board; or
      (4)   By absence, without excuse acceptable to four (4) of the other
members of the Board, from three (3) regular meetings of the Board within one
(1) calendar year.
 
   (c)   Filling of Vacancies.  Any vacancy shall be filled for the remainder
of the unexpired term in the manner the original appointment was made.
(Ord. 2013-027.  Passed 5-21-13.)
 
   157.05  APPLICATION AND NOTICE.
   (a)    Whenever a structure, as defined by the Zoning Ordinance, whether
public or private, within the above described district is proposed to be
constructed, or erected, and whenever an existing structure is proposed to be
altered, reconstructed, or enlarged, if such alteration, construction or
enlargement involves the exterior design, material, finish grade line,
landscaping or orientation of the structure, an application for a certificate
of appropriateness shall be filed with the Secretary of the Architectural
Review Board.
 
   (b)    The application shall be accompanied by a drawing indicating, at a
minimum, the lot dimensions, size, shape, and dimensions of the structure, the
location and orientation of the structure on the lot and the actual or proposed
building setback lines. The application shall be accompanied by a detailed
narrative description of the proposed design or change of design, use of
materials, finish grade line, landscaping and orientation of the structure.
 
   (c)    Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of appropriateness,
which is accompanied by the material required by the provisions of subsection
(b) hereof, the Secretary of the Board shall place such application on the
Board's agenda for a hearing at its next regular meeting. The Secretary shall
further cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the
City, a public notice of the scheduled hearing date of the application together
with a general description of the nature of the application. The applicant
shall be notified by mail of the date and time of the hearing.
   In addition, there shall be a notice posted on the subject property stating
that an application has been filed and the date and time of the hearing. (Ord.
95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.06  STANDARDS FOR REVIEW; CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS.
   (a)    The Board of Architectural Review, in deciding whether to issue a
certificate of appropriateness, shall determine that the application under
consideration is not detrimental to the interest of the Architectural District
and promotes, preserves and enhances the distinctive historical City character
of the community. In conducting its review, the Board shall make examination of
and give consideration to the elements of the application including, but not
necessarily limited to:
      (1)    Building massing, which shall include the viewer's and
pedestrian's visual perspective;
      (2)    Window treatment, which shall include the size, shape and
materials of the individual window units and the overall harmonious
relationship of window openings;
      (3)    Exterior detail and relationships, which shall include all
projection and receding elements of the exterior, including but not limited to,
porches and overhangs and the horizontal or vertical expression which is
conveyed by these elements;
      (4)    Roof shape and materials which shall include type, form and
materials;
      (5)    Materials, texture and color, which shall include a consideration
of material compatibility among various elements of the structure;
      (6)    Compatibility of design and materials, which shall include the
appropriateness of the use of exterior design details;
      (7)    Landscape design and plant materials, which shall include lighting
and the use of landscape details to highlight architectural features or screen
or soften undesirable view;
   
   (b)    In conducting its inquiry and review, the Board may request from the
applicant additional information, as it shall reasonably require. It may
recommend to the applicant changes in the plans that it considers desirable and
may accept a voluntary amendment to the application to include or reflect such
changes. The Board shall keep a record of its proceedings and shall append to
the application copies of information needed to clearly describe any amendment
to it.
 
   (c)    When its review is concluded, the Board will determine by a vote of
its members whether the application for certificate of appropriateness shall be
approved. If approved by four or more of its members, the Board shall return
the application and appended material to the Secretary with the instruction
that the certificate of appropriateness be issued, provided all other
requirements for a building permit, if applicable, are met. The certificate of
appropriateness shall be valid for five years from the date of approval, or
such  extension as may be granted by the Board. If not approved, the Board
shall return the application and appended material to the applicant with a
detailed explanation of all rationale utilized by the Board regarding the
reason for disapproval. (Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.07  PRESERVATION OF PROPERTY UPON DEMOLITION OF A STRUCTURE.
   (a)    Whenever a structure within the Architectural District is proposed to
be demolished, an application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be
filed with the Secretary of the Board of Architectural Review as provided in
this chapter. In considering such application, the Board shall limit its
inquiry to the proposal for grading, landscaping and other design treatment of
the property once the structure has been removed.
 
   (b)    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the demolition
of a structure whether public or private, within the District. (Ord. 95-130.
Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.08  REPAIR OR MAINTENANCE EXCEPTION.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent any ordinary repair or
maintenance of an exterior architectural feature or any ordinary planting and
landscaping now in the Architectural District.  (Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.09  APPEALS.
   The Board of Architectural Review shall decide all applications for
architectural review not later than thirty days after the hearing thereon.
   (a)    Any person, firm or corporation, or any officer, department, board or
agency of  the City who has been aggrieved by any decision of the Board
involving an application for architectural review approval may appeal such
decision to the Board of Building and Zoning Appeals by filing a notice of
appeal to the Board of Zoning Appeals with the Secretary of the Architectural
Review Board within ten days from the date of decision, setting forth the facts
of the case.
   (b)    The Secretary of the Board of Architectural Review shall then forward
the record of the proceeding before the Board of Architectural Review to the
Board of Zoning Appeals who shall then hold a public hearing on the appeal as
provided by law, and shall decide the matter pursuant to Section 1137.16(b) of
the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.10  PLANNING COMMISSION JURISDICTION; CITY BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS.
   This chapter does not alter or affect or infringe upon any of the
jurisdiction of the Planning Commission of the City and is intended to be a new
regulation. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit the power of
any other City Board or Commission.
(Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
   157.99  PENALTY.
   It shall be unlawful to locate, construct, reconstruct, enlarge, change, or
maintain any building or land in violation of this chapter. Any person, firm,
or corporation violating any regulation thereto shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than fifty
dollars ($50.00). Every day during which such illegal location, erection,
construction, reconstruction, enlargement, change, or maintenance continues,
may be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 95-130. Passed 9-5-95.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 159
Board of Park Commissioners

      Memorial Lake Park - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
