CHAPTER 941
Reservoirs and Memorial Lake Park
 
941.01   Definitions.
941.02   Rubber rafts and inner tubes prohibited.
941.03   Use of launching ramps required.
941.04   Launching ramp charge; boat markers.
941.05   Minimum boat lengths.
941.06   Motors on boats restricted.
941.07   Child operators prohibited; exceptions.
941.08   Maximum boat passengers.
941.09   Life preservers required.
941.10   Standing up in or riding sides of boats prohibited.
941.11   Operation of boat while intoxicated prohibited.
941.12   Light on boat at night required.
941.13   Reckless operation of boat prohibited.
941.14   Swimming prohibited.
941.15   Vehicle speed in parks.
941.16   Littering Park grounds prohibited.
941.17   Depositing garbage or rubbish in Lake or reservoirs prohibited.
941.18   Hours vehicles prohibited in Park.
941.19   Application of traffic  regulations.
941.20   Camping areas.
941.21   Non-application of regulations.
941.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
      Board of Park Commissioners - see ADM. Ch.
159
      Pollution of reservoirs - see GEN. OFF.
517.08
      Bulk sale of water prohibited when water level low - see S.U. & P.S.
923.06 (b)
 
   941.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Memorial Lake Park" means all that real property owned by the City
south of State Route 18 and east of Old State Road, inside and outside the
corporate limits, which adjoins the reservoirs owned and operated by the City,
all as more fully set forth on a certain map attached hereto, marked Exhibit A
and incorporated herein by reference.
   (b)   "Memorial Lake" means Reservoir Number 3.
   (c)   "Upper Reservoir" means Reservoir Number 2.
   (d)   "Lower Reservoir' means Reservoir Number 1.
   (Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.02  RUBBER RAFTS AND INNER TUBES PROHIBITED.
   Except as other herein provided, no person shall use on the waters of
Memorial Lake or the Upper Reservoir or Lower Reservoir a rubber, synthetic
rubber or plastic device designed to keep a person afloat, or an inner tube,
life raft or any similar device designed to keep a person afloat.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.03  USE OF LAUNCHING RAMPS REQUIRED.
   Any person launching a rowboat, sailboat or canoe at Memorial Lake, the
Upper Reservoir or the Lower Reservoir shall launch such rowboat, sailboat, or
canoe at the ramp provided at Memorial Lake and at the Upper and Lower
Reservoirs.  This section shall not apply to any individual launching a rowboat
or canoe in a completely manual fashion.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.04  LAUNCHING RAMP CHARGE; BOAT MARKERS.
   (a)   The Board of Park Commission shall have the right to levy up to ten
dollars ($10.00) per year per rowboat, sailboat or canoe for the use of the
ramps at Memorial Lake and the Upper or Lower Reservoirs, all Norwalk residents
are exempt.  The Board of Park Commissioners shall designate the time and place
where such charges shall be paid and shall issue an appropriate marker for each
rowboat, sailboat or canoe.
 
   (b)   No person shall launch a boat without paying the charge provided for
herein.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.05  MINIMUM BOAT LENGTHS.
   No person shall launch a rowboat under eight feet long, a sailboat under ten
feet long or a canoe under twelve feet long on the waters of Memorial Lake or
the Upper or Lower Reservoir.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.06  MOTORS ON BOATS RESTRICTED.
   Boats operated on the waters of Memorial Lake and the Upper or the Lower
Reservoir may be propelled by electric outboard motors of a size not to exceed
one and one-half horsepower, and shall be limited to one motor per boat.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.07  CHILD OPERATORS PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   No person under eighteen years of age shall operate any rowboat,
sailboat or canoe on the water of Memorial Lake or the Upper or Lower Reservoir
unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian or person eighteen
years of age or over.
 
   (b)   No person under eighteen years of age shall be in any rowboat,
sailboat, or canoe unless such person is accompanied by a parent, guardian or
person eighteen years of age or older.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.08  MAXIMUM BOAT PASSENGERS.
   The operator of any rowboat, sailboat or canoe shall not carry more persons
than the number provided by Coast Guard regulations.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.09  LIFE PRESERVERS REQUIRED.
   (a)   Each person in any rowboat, sailboat, or canoe shall carry a Coast
Guard approved life preserver.
 
   (b)   Each person who is on a sailboard in any City reservoir shall wear a
Coast Guard approved life preserver.  (Ord. 97-88.  Passed 7-1-97.)
 
   941.10  STANDING UP IN OR RIDING SIDES OF BOATS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall stand in or ride the sides or deck of any rowboat, sailboat
or canoe while such device is on the waters at Memorial Lake or the Upper or
Lower Reservoir.  This section shall not be construed to prohibit an individual
from standing on a sailboard on Memorial Lake Reservoir.  No person shall stand
on or operate a sailboard on any other reservoir within the City.  (Ord. 97-
87.  Passed 7-1-97.)
 
   941.11  OPERATION OF BOAT WHILE INTOXICATED PROHIBITED.
   No person who is under the influence of alcohol shall separate or be aboard
any rowboat, sailboat or canoe while on the waters of Memorial Lake or the
Upper and Lower Reservoir.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
   941.12  LIGHT ON BOAT AT NIGHT REQUIRED.
   No person shall operate a rowboat, sailboat, or canoe or be at anchor
between sunset and sunrise which does not display at least one continuous white
light visible from all points of the horizon.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.13  RECKLESS OPERATION OF BOAT PROHIBITED.
   No person shall operate a rowboat, sailboat or canoe so as to endanger the
life or limb of any person or operate such rowboat, sailboat or canoe without
due regard for the safety and rights of any person so as to endanger the life,
limb or property of any person.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.14  SWIMMING PROHIBITED.
   No person shall swim in Memorial Lake, or in the Upper Reservoir or Lower
Reservoir; except that swimming shall be permitted as part of an annual
triathlon to be operated by the Norwalk Park & Recreation Department under
proper supervision and only for purposes of the annual event.  (Ord. 2006-035. 
Passed 7-11-06.)
 
   941.15  VEHICLE SPEED IN PARKS.
   No person shall operate a motor vehicle in any City park at a rate of speed
in excess of the posted speed limit. 
(Ord. 2015-032.  Passed 7-21-15.)
 
   941.16  LITTERING PARK GROUNDS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited upon the
ground at Memorial Lake Park any paper, garbage, food, cans, glass, stoneware
or refuse of any kind.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.17  DEPOSITING GARBAGE OR RUBBISH IN LAKE OR RESERVOIRS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be thrown or deposited upon or
in the waters of the Lower Reservoir, Upper Reservoir or Memorial Lake any
paper, garbage, food, cans, glass, stoneware or refuse of any kind.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.18  HOURS VEHICLES PROHIBITED IN PARK.
   No person shall operate a motor vehicle in Memorial Lake Park between
official sunset and official sunrise.  (Ord. 94-73.  Passed 7-19-94.)
 
   941.19  APPLICATION OF TRAFFIC REGULATIONS.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, the provisions of Part Three-Traffic
Code shall be applicable to the roadways and property in Memorial Lake Park.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.20  CAMPING AREAS.
   The Board of Park Commissioners and Board of Control may permit camping in
designated areas, as outlined in the map, in Memorial Lake Park and may adopt
such rules and regulations as they deem necessary to promote such activity.
(Ord. 65-21.  Passed 6-15-65.)
 
   941.21  NON-APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS.
   Sections
941.05 and
941.06 shall not apply to watercraft operated in performance of its duties by
departments or agencies of the City, State and Federal Government.
(Ord. 2015-047.  Passed 11-17-15.)
 
   941.99  PENALTY.
   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
minor misdemeanor for each separate offense.
(Ord. 81-15.  Passed 4-7-81.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 943
Trees
 
943.01   Definitions.
943.02   Ownership and control of public trees.
943.03   Creation and establishment of a  City Tree Board.
943.04   Term of office and vacancy.
943.05   Compensation.
943.06   Duties and responsibilities.
943.07   Operation.
943.08   Public tree species to be planted.
943.09   Spacing.
943.10   Distance from curb and sidewalk.
943.11   Distance from street corners and fireplugs.
943.12   Utilities.
943.13   Public tree care.
943.14   Tree topping.
943.15   Pruning, corner clearance.
943.16   Dead or diseased tree removal on private property.
943.17   Removal of stumps.
943.18   Interference with Board.
943.19   Arborist’s license and bond.
943.20   Clerk of City Tree Board.
943.21   Restrictions on planting and removal of public trees.
943.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Injury or destruction of trees - see GEN. OFF.
541.06
      Permit to trim trees to avoid utility lines - see S.U. & P.S.
927.09 (b)
 
 
 
   943.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this Chapter, the following terms shall have the
meanings indicated:
   (a)   "Street tree" means any tree, shrub, bush and any other woody
vegetation on land lying between the paved edge of all streets, avenues or ways
within the City and the adjacent sidewalk, and any tree, shrub, bush and any
other woody vegetation lying within the right-of-way of all streets, avenues or
ways within the City.
   (b)   "Park tree" means any tree, shrub, bush and any other woody vegetation
on property located within public parks or other areas owned by the City.
   (c)   "Public tree" means all street trees and all park trees.
      (Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.02  OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL OF PUBLIC TREES.
   All public trees lying within the City of Norwalk shall be subject to the
ownership and control of the City. All public trees may be maintained, trimmed,
planted and removed by the City as provided in this Chapter. (Ord. 2013-034. 
Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.03  CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A CITY TREE BOARD.
   There is hereby created and established a City Tree Board for the City,
which shall consist of five members, citizens and residents of this City, who
shall be appointed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.04  TERM OF OFFICE AND VACANCY.
   (a)   The term of the five persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be
three years except that the term of two of the members appointed to the first
Board shall be for only one year and the term of two members of the first Board
shall be for two years.
   (b)   A member of the City Tree Board shall vacate his/her office and shall
cease to be a member upon his/her removal of his/her residence from the City,
death, written resignation delivered to the Clerk of the Tree Board, or his/her
absence that is not excused by a vote of three of the other members of the
Board from three meetings of the Board in one calendar year.
   (c)   In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member,
his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.05  COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Board shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.06  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   It shall be the responsibility of the Board to study, investigate,
counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for
the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition
of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such
plan will be presented annually to Council and upon their acceptance and
approval shall constitute the official comprehensive City Tree Plan for the
City.
   (b)   The Board, when requested by Council, shall consider, investigate,
make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming
within the scope of its work.
   (c)   Upon the request of the Safety/Service Director the Board shall render
advice on the planting or removal of any tree subject to the jurisdiction of
the City.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.07  OPERATION.
   The Board shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and regulations
and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a
quorum for the transaction of business.  (Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.
   943.08  PUBLIC TREE SPECIES TO BE PLANTED.
   A list of the official public tree species shall be compiled and updated by
the City Tree Board, and shall be made available in the office of the Safety/
Service Director. The list shall divide the applicable species into three
categories, by average height:
   (a)   Small trees that are less than thirty feet;
   (b)   Medium trees that are from thirty to forty-five feet; and
   (c)   Large trees that are over forty-five feet.
      (Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.09  SPACING.
   (a)   The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three
species size classes listed in Section
943.08, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following:
      (1)   Small Trees, thirty feet;
      (2)   Medium Trees, forty feet;
      (3)   Large Trees, forty feet.
   (b)   Special plantings in deviation of the foregoing, designed by a
landscape architect, may be approved by the City Tree Board.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.10  DISTANCE FROM CURB AND SIDEWALK.
   (a)   The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and
sidewalks will be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in
Section
943.08, and no trees may be placed closer to any curb or sidewalk than the
following:
      (1)   Small trees, two feet;
      (2)   Medium Trees, three feet;
      (3)   Large Trees, four feet.
   (b)   Exceptions for narrower spaces may be approved by the City Tree Board.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.11  DISTANCE FROM STREET CORNERS AND FIREPLUGS.
   No Street Tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet of any street
corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. No
Street Tree shall be planted closer than ten feet of any fireplug.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.12  UTILITIES.
   No street tree other than those species listed as Small Trees in Section
943.08 may be planted over, under or within 10 lateral feet of any overhead
utility wire, sewer line, transmission line or other utility.  (Ord. 2013-034. 
Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.13  PUBLIC TREE CARE.
   (a)   The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove
trees, plants and shrubs lying within or over-hanging the lines of all streets,
alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds, as may be necessary to
insure public safety, preserve utilities or to preserve or enhance the health
and integrity of public trees.
   (b)   The City may remove or cause to be removed, any tree or part thereof
which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious
to streets, sidewalks, sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or
other public improvements or infra-structure, or is affected with any injurious
fungus, insect or other pest.
   (c)   Upon the request of the City the Tree Board shall render advice on the
matters set forth in Sections
943.13(a) and (b).
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.14  TREE TOPPING.
   It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm, or City
Department to top any public tree. Topping is defined as the severe cutting
back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's
crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the
tree. Trees that are severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain
trees where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this
chapter at the determination of the City Tree Board. 
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.15  PRUNING, CORNER CLEARANCE.
   (a)   Every owner of any tree overhanging any sidewalk, street or right-of-
way within the City shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not
obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street
intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the
surface of the street or sidewalk. The owners shall remove all dead, diseased
or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the
safety of the public. The City shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub
on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along
the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic
control device or sign or otherwise obstructs traffic on any sidewalk or
street.
   (b)   For the purposes of this Section, the owner of any lot or land
adjacent to any sidewalk, street or right-of-way shall be deemed to be the
owner of any tree located on said lot or land.  (Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-
13.)
   943.16  DEAD OR DISEASED TREE REMOVAL ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   The City, with the advice of the Tree Board, shall have the right to cause
the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the City,
when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property, or harbor insects or
disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the City. The
City shall notify in writing the owners of such trees. Removal shall be done by
such owners at their own expense within sixty days after the date of service of
notice. In the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the
City shall have the authority to remove such trees. The cost of such removal
may be recovered from the owners in a civil suit or, at the option of the City,
may be certified to the County Auditor and shall become a lien on the owner's
property as with other taxes.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.17  REMOVAL OF STUMPS.
   Except as otherwise approved by the Safety/Service Director all stumps of
public trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top
of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.18  INTERFERENCE WITH BOARD.
   No person to prevent, delay or interfere with the Safety/Service Director,
the City Tree Board, or any of its agents, while carrying out the duties of
this Chapter and otherwise engaging in and about the planting, cultivating,
mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any public trees, or trees on
private grounds as authorized in this chapter.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.19  ARBORIST’S LICENSE AND BOND.
   (a)   No person or firm shall engage in the business or occupation of
pruning, treating, or removing public trees within the City without first
applying for and procuring a license from the Office of the Safety/Service
Director.
   (b)   The license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually in
advance.
   (c)   No license shall be required of any public utility service company,
its agents, or any City employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public
endeavors.
   (d)   Each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability
insurance in the minimum amounts for bodily injury and property damage, in
amounts set annually by the Tree Board, indemnifying the City or any person
injured or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein
described.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.20  CLERK OF CITY TREE BOARD.
   The City Tree Board shall appoint a Clerk, who shall be a person other than
the Clerk of Council, to serve as Clerk to the City Tree Board, and who shall
be the keeper of records and perform such other duties as the Board may assign.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.21  RESTRICTIONS ON PLANTING AND REMOVAL OF PUBLIC TREES.
   (a)   No person shall plant any tree, shrub, bush and any other woody
vegetation on land lying between the paved edge of all streets, avenues or ways
within the City and the adjacent sidewalk, and any tree, shrub, bush and any
other woody vegetation lying within the right-of-way of all streets, avenues or
ways within the City, or within public parks or other areas owned by the City,
without the prior written approval of the Safety/Service Director.
   (b)   No person shall prune or remove any tree, shrub, bush and any other
woody vegetation on land lying between the paved edge of all streets, avenues
or ways within the City and the adjacent sidewalk, and any tree, shrub, bush
and any other woody vegetation lying within the right-of-way of all streets,
avenues or ways within the City, or within public parks or other areas owned by
the City, without the prior written approval of the Safety/Service Director.
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
   943.99  PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be, upon conviction
or a plea of guilty or no contest, subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred
fifty dollars ($150.00).
(Ord. 2013-034.  Passed 6-18-13.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 945
Garbage and Rubbish
 
945.01   Definitions.
945.02   System of garbage pickup.
945.03   Extra service.
945.04   Limited back yard pick up.
945.05   Prohibitions.
945.06   Duty to have garbage and refuse removed.
945.07   Littering and deposit of refuse.
945.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Collection and disposal of garbage - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
      Employment of scavengers - see Ohio R.C. 3707.39
      Vehicle loads dropping or leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
 
   945.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following words shall be defined as follows:
   (a)   “Refuse” means all kitchen waste and general household trash and
unless otherwise provided for by law or the Service/Safety Director, does not
include grass clippings, weeds, bushes, brush clippings, trees, tree branches,
leaves, or tree branch clippings, earth, sod, rocks, concrete, refuse from
construction or remodeling, lumber, motor vehicle parts, tires, any liquids, or
metal appliances, sofas, tables, or other similar furniture.
   (b)   “Garbage can” means a tapered container designed for holding refuse
having a maximum volume of thirty gallons, weighing not more than forty pounds
when filled with refuse and having a secure lid and being in good condition. 
It does not include barrels of any kind.
   (c)   “Bag” means a standard polyvinyl type minimum two mill thickness
container, having a maximum volume of thirty gallons and weighing no more than
forty pounds when filled with refuse.
   (d)   “Resident’ means a homeowner, tenant or other person occupying or
having the right to possession and control of a dwelling.
   (e)   “Garbage” includes refuse, yard waste and brush.
   (f)   “Yard wastes” means leaves, grass, weeds, branches less than four feet
in length, small twigs, brush and other vegetation capable of being contained
in a can supplied by a resident pursuant to Section
945.02(b).  Yard waste does not include any tree or part of a tree with an
aggregate weight of greater than forty pounds.
   (g)   “Garbage collection services” means the collection, storage, and
disposal of all refuse, yard waste and brush and all services or work
necessarily related thereto.
   (h)   “General household trash” includes but is not limited to ashes,
discarded toys, discarded clothing and similar materials and goods.
   (i)   “Recyclable” means plastic or glass bottles or jars, newspaper,
magazines and like materials, aluminum or steel cans.
   (j)   “Brush bundle” means a bundle of brush and branch clippings securely
bound, not exceeding four feet in length and not exceeding forty pounds.
      (Ord. 97-80.  Passed 6-17-97.)
 
   945.02  SYSTEM OF GARBAGE PICKUP.
   (a)   Refuse.
      (1)   Except as otherwise provided by law, the City shall, at no charge,
pick up refuse produced by residents within the confines of the City once a
week, in accordance with a schedule established by the Director of Public
Service and Safety.
      (2)   The City shall pick up a maximum of three bags or cans or
combination thereof, with a total maximum capacity not to exceed 100 gallons or
120 pounds for each dwelling house or apartment unit.
         (Ord.  97-81.  Passed 6-17-97.)
      (3)   Every can of refuse placed for curbside pickup shall have a secure
lid, free of leaks, covering the top of the can.  The City may not pick up any
can of refuse without a lid so secured.
         (Ord.  2000-81.  Passed 11-14-00.)
 
   (b)   Yard Waste.
      (1)   Mobile home, modular homes or houses.  Each resident household
occupying a mobile home, modular home, manufactured home or house located
within the limits of the City shall be entitled to have the City pick up yard
waste generated on such real property in cans supplied by the resident as
follows:
         A.   The Service Director shall establish a schedule for the pick-up
of yard waste within the City.
         B.   Yard waste will be picked up by the City when such waste is
placed in brush bundles or when placed within a can to be supplied by the
resident.  Such can shall be no larger than thirty gallons and shall weigh no
more than forty pounds when filled.
         C.   Yard waste shall be placed in such cans as are to be free from
refuse.
         D.   The City shall be required to pick up a maximum of two yard waste
cans.
      (2)   Apartments.  Each apartment building containing dwelling or living
units wherein persons occupy and reside shall be entitled to place up to two
cans containing yard waste per apartment building in conformity with above.
 
   (c)   Recycling.  To encourage recycling activities, the City will, free of
charge, pick up all properly identified recyclables.
 
   (d)   The City shall not be responsible for picking up any garbage as
defined within this chapter from any property where the Safety/Service Director
determines that access to such property is obstructed, unsafe, or blocked.  In
the event the Safety/Service Director determines that access to such property
is obstructed, unsafe or blocked, the Service Director shall notify the owner
or custodian of such property to remove or cause to remove such garbage and it
shall then be the responsibility of the owner of such property or the custodian
of such property to have such garbage removed and properly discarded at their
cost.  Any refuse remaining in such property for more than one day after the
Service Director provides the notice mentioned herein shall constitute a public
nuisance and shall subject the owner or custodian of such property to any
penalties provided in Chapter
521 of the General Offenses Code.
 
   (e)   Unless otherwise provided by the Service Director, yard waste shall be
picked up as provided herein by the City between April 1 to November 1 of any
particular year.
 
   (f)   Compost.  The City shall provide without charge to the citizens of the
City the ability to dispose of yard waste, compost and related material at a
compost pile located at a compost area within the City as provided herein:
      (1)   The City shall operate, maintain, staff, and police a compost area
upon which a compost pile shall exist, on property owned by the City, west of
Plank Road on Austie Shadle Drive.
      (2)   The compost area and the compost pile shall be staffed as
determined by the Mayor and Service Director with such hours of operation as
determined by the Service Director, and which hours shall be posted
accordingly.
      (3)   No person shall deposit compost, yard waste or any other matter on
the compost pile at such time as the compost area and pile is closed, nor shall
any person, unless otherwise authorized by the City, enter onto the compost
area during a time that such area is closed.
      (4)   No person who is not a resident of the City shall use the compost
area or deposit yard waste, compost or any other material on the compost pile. 
Any person desiring to use the compost pile or compost area shall first provide
the City with a valid driver’s license.  No person shall use the compost area
or compost pile without first producing such license.  No person shall be
admitted to the compost pile or compost area without such license.
      (5)   No person shall deposit any material on the compost pile that is
not yard waste, compost or related material.  In addition to any other penalty
provided by law, any person attempting to deposit such material may be asked to
leave the compost area by the City.
      (6)   No person shall use the compost area or pile for commercial
purposes or for a commercially related activity.
         (Ord. 97-81.  Passed 6-17-97.)
 
   945.03  EXTRA SERVICE.
   The City shall provide extra pick up service in accordance with this
section.  The City shall sell a marker device for three dollars ($3.00) each. 
Such device, when placed on a bag or can not exceeding 33 gallons in capacity
shall entitle the resident to have the bag or can picked up and shall be valid
for one pick up only.  The City shall also sell a marker device for ten dollars
($10.00) each.  Such device, when placed on a bag, can, furniture or appliance
free of freon, shall entitle the resident to have the bag, can, furniture or
appliance free of freon picked up and shall be valid for one pick up only. 
(Ord. 2009-053.  Passed 11-17-09.)
 
   945.04  LIMITED BACK YARD PICK UP.
   On application, the Director of Public Service and Safety shall allow back
yard pick-up to those residents who have a physical disability or infirmity
which makes it impossible or impracticable for the resident to carry refuse or
yard waste materials to the curb.
(Ord. 97-68.  Passed 5-27-97.)
 
   945.05  PROHIBITIONS.
   (a)   Except as provided by law, no person shall allow refuse to accumulate
for a period to exceed one week.
 
   (b)   No person shall pick up refuse on the curbside location except for the
City.
 
   (c)   All residents shall remove empty cans from the curbside location by 6:
00 a.m. of the day following the pick up.
 
   (d)   No resident shall place cans or bags for curbside pick up prior to 4:
00 p.m. to the day preceding the day of trash pick up.
 
   (e)   No person shall violate Section
945.02(a) or (b) by exceeding the number of bags, cans or volume listed in
945.02(a), or failing to comply with the placement requirements contained in
subsection
945.02(b).
 
   (f)   No person shall, without the authority of the property owner, deposit
for pick up any garbage or refuse.
 
   (g)   No garbage generated outside of the limits of the City, through
commercial, industrial or residential usage, shall be deposited for pick up by
the City of Norwalk Sanitation Department.
 
   (h)   No person shall place batteries, tires, hazardous materials in the
form of solids or liquids or construction debris, for pick up by the City of
Norwalk Sanitation Department.
 
   (i)   No person shall place refuse in a can when the can cannot hold such
refuse due to cracks or holes in such can.  Any such can will not be picked up
by the City and shall be removed from the curbside location by 6:00 a.m.
following the pick up.
 
   (j)   No person shall place syringes or needles for pick up by the City of
Norwalk Sanitation Department unless such are in an approved disposal storage
unit.
(Ord. 97-69.  Passed 5-27-97.)
 
   945.06  DUTY TO HAVE GARBAGE AND REFUSE REMOVED.
   Any person producing or having garbage or refuse shall remove the same or
cause it to be removed by properly authorized persons.
(Ord. 63-30.  Passed 10-1-63.)
 
   945.07  LITTERING AND DEPOSIT OF REFUSE.
   No person producing or having refuse in the City shall deposit or place the
same on any street, alley, or public place or ground, or private property in
the City, except on grounds owned by or under the control of the person
responsible for such refuse, or throw the same in any stream or body of water
in the City.  All persons are hereby required to collect such refuse in
suitable receptacles or piles upon the premises in the possession of the person
responsible therefor, then destroy such refuse in the manner authorized by the
Board of Health, or remove such refuse to the landfill or compost site,
provided by the City, at the expense of the person responsible therefor.  In
whichever manner disposed of, the premises shall be so cleared of refuse as
often as necessary not in excess of every thirty days, so as to eliminate any
nuisance to the public.
(Ord. 89-63.  Passed 10-17-89.)
 
   945.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor.  Each day on which a violation occurs or continues shall be deemed
a separate offense.

CHAPTER 1101
Planning Commission
 
1101.01   Planning Commission.
1101.02   Powers and duties.
1101.03   To be Platting Commission; duties.
1101.04   Division of City into zones.
1101.05   Zoning permits for public buildings.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
      Charter provisions - see CHTR. Sec.
6.02,
6.03
      Plat approval required - see Ohio R.C. 711.09
      Powers of Board of Building and Zoning Appeals - see P. & Z.
1137.02
      Zoning Ordinance changes and amendments - see P. & Z. Ch.
1143
 
   1101.01  PLANNING COMMISSION.
   (a)   There shall be a Planning Commission composed of seven members,
qualified electors of the City, as follows:
      (1)   Three members shall be appointed by the Chief Executive Officer and
four members shall be appointed by Council.
      (2)   Of those initially appointed by the Chief Executive Officer, one
shall be appointed for two years, and one for four years.  The third member
shall be appointed for a term ending November 30, 1975.  Thereafter, they shall
be appointed for a full four year term.
   Of those initially appointed by Council, one shall be appointed for one
year, one for three years, and one for four years.  The fourth member shall be
appointed for a term ending November 30, 1974.  Thereafter, they shall be
appointed for a full four year term.
 
   (b)   Any vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term in
the manner the original appointment was made. (Ord. 75-58.  Passed 8-7-75.)
 
   1101.02  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)    The Planning Commission shall have and exercise all powers conferred
upon Planning Commissions by general law and such other duties assigned by this
Charter and shall, advise the Chief Executive Officer and Council on needed
changes in the Master Plan, the Subdivision Platting Ordinance, the Official
City Map, and the Zoning Ordinance.
 
   (b)   The Commission shall adopt rules and bylaws governing the transaction
of its business and the exercise of its power, such as shall not be in conflict
with any of the ordinances of the City. It shall elect a chairman, a vice-
chairman and a secretary. The secretary may or may not be a member of the
Commission. All meetings of the Commission shall be open to the public and the
Commission shall keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members
shall constitute a quorum and the concurrence of a majority of the members
shall be necessary to determine any question of matter before the Commission.
(Ord. 78-33. Passed by General Election 11-7-78.)
 
   1101.03  TO BE PLATTING COMMISSION; DUTIES.
   The Planning Commission shall be the Platting Commission, and is empowered
and authorized to control the heights, design, and location of buildings, and
to appoint or employ architects, engineers and other professional services and
other employees as it shall deem necessary. The expenditures for such services
and employments shall be within the amounts appropriated for such persons by
Council. The Planning Commission shall have all other duties and powers as may
be authorized by ordinance or the general laws of Ohio. (1961 Code §236.)
 
   1101.04  DIVISION OF CITY INTO ZONES.
   The Planning Commission shall have the power to frame and adopt a plan for
dividing the City or any portion thereof into zones or districts, representing
the recommendations of the Commission, in the interest of the public health,
safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity or general welfare for the limitations
and regulation of the height, bulk and location, including percentage of lot
occupancy, setback building lines and area and dimensions of yards, courts and
other open spaces, and the uses of buildings and other structures and of
premises in such zones or districts. (1961 Code §237.)
 
   1101.05  ZONING PERMITS FOR PUBLIC BUILDINGS.
   (a)   Definitions.
      (1)   A “public building” means any building constructed or authorized to
be constructed by the State of Ohio or any political subdivision thereof, or of
any other state or governmental entity, or
      (2)   Any building constructed to be used by the State of Ohio or any
political subdivision thereof, or of any other state or governmental entity.
   (b)   Any person or entity constructing a public building as defined by this
section shall make application for a zoning permit to the Zoning Inspector who,
within 5 working days therefrom, shall cause said application to be forwarded
to the Secretary of the Planning Commission.
   (c)   Upon receipt of the application for a zoning permit as described in
subsection (b) hereof, the Secretary of the Planning Commission shall cause the
application to be brought before the Planning Commission within 10 working days
of the Secretary’s receipt of the application.
   (d)   Upon receipt of the application for construction of a public building
or part thereof, the Planning Commission shall render its decision authorized
under
Section 6.04 of the Charter pertaining to the construction of public
buildings.  No public building or part thereof shall be constructed or
authorized to be constructed unless the location, character, and extent thereof
are approved by the Planning Commission as required by Ohio Revised Code
713.02.
(Ord. 2003-076.  Passed 12-16-03.)
 
 
 
TITLE THREE - Subdivision Regulations
         Chap.
